I really wanted to like this. I should know better than to trust Peter Bradshaw, critic for the Guardian, but everything sounded right. I really was willing to give it every chance, even waiting for the tragedy that had Peter Bradshaw crying first time he watched it.The only tragedy with this film is that it is so tedious. The characters are two-dimensional. The plot, such as it is, is OK - it's a kind of everyday miserable life in Latin America if you're not in the posh classes. For servants, it can be rough, although not particularly for the ones in this particular household.Then there's the cinematography. I think someone else has mentioned the panning. It never stops. In the streets, in the house, the camera goes on forever, adding minutes of time that I will never get back, without adding anything to the story.The filming itself is nice and sharp, but that has the odd effect of making it feel consciously like a film set. Just too staged, and not at all that kind of fly on the wall feel you get from some movies that drag you into the characters' minds and lives.There's a sense of impending doom that the plodding plotline can't really pull off. To be honest, the whole movie could have done with a bit more tragedy, and maybe a bit less wooden acting. Yes, I know the one person is not a professional actor, but that doesn't make her acting any good, or believable.I regret watching this. The three stars are mainly because it's an interesting subject, and it does capture a bit of the zeitgeist of the early 1970s. But it could have been much, much better.

Review title: An excellent film but not for everyone.
Review_body: I watched this film alone and I do not regret it. I am coming from a country with a lot of similarities with Mexico, my husband is from Europe and far from growing up in similar situations as the depicted here. I did grew up with the help of many wonderful women that did far more than to clean the house. I was deeply moved by the film. I can not stop thinking on those wonderful persons who gave me so much love. It just transport in time and had a lot of flash-backs about my own life... I guess people who grew in a different culture or another time may struggle to appreciate how genuine and beautiful in its simplicity this film is. That is why I guess many persons on the comments were not moved by it and did not like it. I really thank someone put the struggle of so many woman who work on the most hard conditions and often with so little payment to make us think about them. It is slow but I recommended on particular If you live it during the same time period and type of culture... or If you want to learn about it.

Review title: 'Roma' is one of the most wonderful films of the decade: a prodigious work of art
Review_body: Rome ', more than a movie, is a piece of life. A piece of the heart of Cuarón in which the Mexican, in a prodigious exercise both in form and substance, and combining a sincere nostalgia, a great claim component, and an emotional scale as dazzling as the amalgam of grays in his photography, which is not afraid to drastically change from the tender to the heartbreaking, it makes an eternal secondary in real life an unexpected protagonist. An incidental thread that serves as an excuse for the director to capture on screen an era, a setting, a socio-political climate, textures, an amalgam of memories and a veritable whirlwind of sensations on the surface. A sample of unbeatable cinema, unique and unrepeatable that invites us to observe, judge and remember with its architect a brief passage of its existence with the greatest authenticity; which, in the times that it runs, is something unpayable.
It's like The Help, but in Mexico and no one sh!ts in a pie.

Review title: Not a regular Hollywood Best Seller, but quite exceptional though
Review_body: I've read a lot of the reviews and most of the people complain about being boring, stupid, non sense, etc.Those are the same kind of comments I've heard from friends (I'm writing from Mexico City), and it wasn't in my plans to watch this movie. However one night I had no better choices and decided to give it a try.It's partially true that the plot is weak. But I think that's precisely the point the director wanted to make. Before watching this movie you have to get rid of stereotypes all together, and simply enjoy with an open minded attitude. Because this one is not the well-known formula most of the people like to watch in a movie.It's basically about the life of a maid in the early 70's in Mexico. How she fits into the family, the sort of problems she deals with due to the lack of academic education and common sense, and finally, the way society worked in that time. But yeah, the maid is the main character of the movie.So, for starters, if you don't find anything appealing about knowing how a maid lived in Mexico City 50 years, go do yourself a favor and don't be stupid enough to watch this movie, expecting the adrenaline of the Avengers or such, if you know what I mean.However if you're like me, who happened to live his childhood during that time, then maybe it is worth watching. But you need to understand there is actually no plot. It is basically the introspective of the life of someone, as regular as a maid. Nothing truly amazing about that. She doesn't fight the super bad guys, neither becomes a rock star or a rich software developer. It's 1971, it's Mexico City, and again, it's a maid from Oaxaca, one of the poorest states in Mexico.Overall I could not rate the movie over 8, not because it is not good. It is indeed. But I trend to keep higher ratings for movies that truly make me wonder about something. This one is not the case. But I cried like a baby when I saw this, and probably you will to.Hope this feedback can encourage others or prevent more disappointed ones, depending on your case. Cheers.

...that's all I got. A year in the life of a maid in Mexico, and the family she works for. Several gripping scenes, but then no follow up. I just never was fully invested emotionally. Maybe check it out again in a few years and get a better perspective. Also, if I want to see numerous shots of dog waste, I'll walk by my neighborhood park.
What a disappointment, where's the story ...really where's it

Review title: GOOD THING THEY DIDNT BUY THAT CRIB!!
Review_body: No. Pointless and meandering first 80%, so you get dulled (yes some good moments that mean nothing) so the 2 shockers at the end have more impact.I realize their trick: Netflix KNOWS no one will sit through this crap at home to get to the big ending. SO - they put it in theaters where you are captive and have a better screen and sound. Then everyone will read the GOOD reviews and sit through it at home. I won't say those last 2 big scenes aren't great - they are - but only in contrast to the stupefying boredom of the first 80%, and only because they use the cheapest "trick" in film - to have death and children mixed together. Thays the easiest and dumbest ploy to get you to "feel."Skip it. See something better.

Review title: Full of Life.. A must watch movie
Review_body:
Full of life in every shot, Alfonso Cuaron has proven that he is one of the greatest directors of all time.
Deserved every nomination and it's going do dominate the Oscars for Sure.

I watched two other movies that where nominated for best foreign film 2018 (one beeinng from my own country, both filmed in B&W) and I have to say Roma had the strongest impact on me.
This story about two women at the end of opposite spectrums in terms of social class and life style, struggle with similar life blows - betrayal by loved ones, isolation and fear. What draws you in is the intimacy and simplicity of the camera work and also the plot. Street vendors and dog poo carry larger meaning than usually as they intensify memories of sounds, smells. The film is filled with stills of naturemort scenes, hypnotising the viewer and giving it plenty of time to process the significance of these moments. It's as if viewer is lifted into a children's and the servant's perspective, cutting therefore all the rest of the noise out. The camera work is at times literally as a pause on flashbacks, a meditative reflection. The film inspires us to look back into our childhood and to remember the people there, the stories and characters that often go unnoticed, disappearing into the void of past.

Review title: A Beautiful Slice of Life-Making the Mundane Extraordinary
Review_body:
This film is not plot driven. Because it's not plot driven each scene holds the viewer for longer then your usual film. I feel like with most films it's one scene and there's a rush to get to the next, always looking ahead to what's going to happen when the scene is over. This film is different in that it takes it's time for you to get to know and understand it and draw your own conclusions from it. It is a slow burner with no real goal or end point in sight other that just being. And for most people's lives I think that's realistic. From day to day most of what we do is pretty mundane with extraordinary moments thrown into the mix. This film makes the mundane beautiful. From the running of the tap, to the rain tapping on the window to the time consuming chore of turning all the lights off at the end of the day, you feel like you're really there.
This film was really reminiscient of 'The Florida Project', one of my favourites, The acting was really superb and at some points during the film I forgot it was fiction and it was like watching a real life account of someone's life.
I found this film really comforting in many ways. One of the loveliest scenes was when all the family were on the sofa watching a movie and Cleo joined in. There was something really homely and inviting about it which was pretty incredible considering it was black and white. And because it was in black and white it made every other sense heightened. You could hear every background noise, every smell and sense every atmosphere. There were many points throughout the film where I was acually imagining the colours. Lighting also played a really key part too, demonstrating the level of ambience that permeated the film,
I found this film really calming in a lot of ways which is why when it drew its conclusion it was even more hard hitting then I expected.Superbly acted, superbly shot. Worth a watch.

Painfully slow isn't a term I'd usually use as I'm a fan of many slow developing movies but Roma takes it to an extreme.Nothing brings the audience in until the 50 minute mark.This movie is overhyped for being an artsy film but there are many others available to invest your time in.

The cinematography, filming,editing is great and Cuaron deserves a huge bravo for that.Director really shows us how skilled he is at his job. Unfortunately it feels that the movie is like a boring documentary,I actually got bored by the story and could not get attached to film protagonists. The technical aspects of the film is great like it was with Gravity but other than that it's "hollow". The black and white filming is also good but I prefer "Cold War" for this year Oscars.
...one of the worst movies ever made. I mean...what is the point of this? That is all.

Review title: Director shows off at actors' expense
Review_body: The reason critics love this film is that the camerawork is stunning and it has many subtle allusions. If you love to study the nuanced choices great actors make then watch a different show.I was pleasantly surprised that the black and white photography added a crispness to the imagery that shows off what a high definition TV can do. But I was greatly disappointed that no theatres showed it the launch week in Calgary (Dec 21, 2018).The story is filled with symbolism an English teacher like me will love. But the extended male nudity will deter much classroom usage.And the plot? Most people crave a problem that worsens before it gets resolved. Many tiny problems here have no development, an opportunity missed in favour of seeming "realism". It ends up coming across like a documentary before music and narration have been added. A hundred years from now kids will be refashioning this film with a score, which it does not have, and some voice over, to see if more tension can be created. My guess is that it will become a film-class darling. Until then...

This was a beautifully shot master raft from Alfonso Cuarón with the kind of gentleness that you will see from the likes of Steven Spielberg in the film Schindler's List, and many other films where they resonate as highly personal. From the opening to the closing you can see the kind of detail that was put into the steady objective view that Cuarón laces throughout the entire film. The issue here lies within the script. Although I generally enjoy these kinds of character films, I found myself caring very little for the female lead despite her quiet and thoughtful performance. I wish that the kind of care and patience in each shot was translated to the script because it felt like it was dragging at multiple points in the movie. Reluctantly, I watched this movie in four sittings because I found that I cared very little to finish it other than the fact that it will be highly relevant come Oscar season. Expect to see this film take home some big statues including Best Director and Best Foreign Language Film, but don't make any bets on this thing taking home Best Picture. This does not carry the same weight and intensity as other films released this year, nor does it have the staying power to make it resonate with future (or present day audiences).

Many reviews say the movie bored them, or that they felt nothing after having watched it. This is by design. When you are done with the movie, you feel just like the people in the movie, and you are supposed to relate to that.. you've been tricked.

Review title: A beautiful photo album , but ultimately dull
Review_body: This film is beautifully shot and though in black and white looks very colourful. Long shots give you every opportunity to appreciate the scenes. But for me this was a very incomplete movie as it is ultimately very dull. It reminded me of looking through a family album of great photos but like most family albums they are really only of interest to the family involved.

Scenario: A mosaic of events, there is no main plot.This fact itself makes you say "so what"?
Characters are shallow and not explained, unbelievably given how long the duration of the film is. For example, why do the children love one maid over the other? What was the relationship between the mother and her husband before the abrupt and inexplicable (at least to the viewers) abandonment?
Pseudo-feminism cliche: good women (the heart of the family and of the country) vs bad men (they are heartless and destroy everything). Open minded upper-class people, how are large enough to consider maids a true part of the family. In the 70's Mexico. Yeah, right...
Positive aspects of the film: Impressive representation of the 1970 Mexican times. Excellent photography. Many scenes with masterful cinematography (eg the scene at the hospital and that at the sea).Summary: a good movie. No more than that. Very overrated. I was kinda bored watching it...

Review title: A sad story in black and white
Review_body: A sad story in black and white makes the story even sadder. Is there a story? You look at the sad live of a upperclass woman and the even sadder live of a servant. After half a hour the story begins. Just on the moment that i thought about leaving the cinema !!!

Technically is beautiful, a black and white that calls more to look beautiful, it is captivating and emotional, it is impossible to imagine this film in color. The simplicity of things, which are accompanied by a powerful message in between are even more shocking and leave you speechless. It's impossible to talk about the narrative, technical and visual achievements of this film as a whole without mentioning them when you write about them.One as a Latino can identify and feel very close to the story, but the most impressive thing is that the film speaks directly to the intellectual reasoning of each of us so that the film sounds like a social echo that amazed our feelings with a series of facts that, beyond looking real, can be done. It is a reality reflected in a fiction.Since Blade Runner 2049, I haven't been deeply moved for while.

Big Cuaron's failure by forcing each of his memories from the 70s one scene after the next. Acting and the ending were the only good thing. Sounded like Cuaron saying "Do you remember how the cars didnt fit in the garages? Do you remember how the garbage truck passed with the garbage man ringing the bell? Do you remember how the clothes were washed? Do you remember the movie theatres?.. Do you remember going to watch the movie? Do you remember the magazine stand? Do you remember..? And ...? ". Disappointing.

So much to enjoy here.
Beautiful acted, perfect pace and so good to watch a b&w film, so much colour.

I went into this movie with an understanding of Mexican history but this movie was a whole lot of nothing. I really can't believe that this won the golden globe for best picture. In addition the direction was disjoined and you were having to wonder what was actually going on and what you needed to pay attention to and if you were missing anything....but you weren't.
This is the perfect movie if you need help falling asleep at night.

Review title: A beautiful film, but not for everyone.
Review_body: This is a beautiful movie with a sweet and sad story done in a, to many, unusual style.There are many who don't like it. And that's fair. But that doesn't make it a bad movie. It offers something quite different than Hollywood movies which is a low key story from the common/lower ends of a Latin society. It's not about being pretentious it's about the expectations you have for a movie. If you watch movies for the plot then it likely isn't a movie for you. This is a movie about low key storytelling.It's an acquired taste much like other kinds of culture. Most people who love pop music probably wouldn't like classical music. That's not because it's bad it just doesn't live up to what they except from music. This is the case with this movie. It's not a movie that leaves you contemplating life or a lifechanging experience or a story you just have to dig deeper into, it is just the foundation of what all movies are in a sense: a story. Without all the glamour and extra things we are used to (for example there's no music to emphasise anything anywhere). The dialogue is simple, and we are simply passengers in this little story.We are just so used to movies having the classic disposition of build up point of no return climax etc with main character development or plot moving in one direction but that's not all a movie (or life) is. Sometimes stories are circular and the profound experiences that we do have end up leaving us where we began. Things change but they also don't. Life doesn't always progress forwardly, but it's always moving whether in circles, forwards or backwards.People say it's boring and I think that's wrong. It's not an exciting movie, but it's well done and it isn't boring. I can rarely watch a movie without checking my phone or getting boring but I barely blinked. I found the story to be captivating and beautiful and intriguing. This felt like a real story that could go anywhere. It was not predictable and it was well told. It isn't about that big plot twist or culmination in the end, it's just a movie moving at a slow pace which isn't trying to reach and overarch anywhere.A great and beautiful movie, but atypical and not something you should just put on to watch if you're bored. This movie is specifically not hollow entertainment and it's also not grandiose. It's low key and very simple and in many ways it's a movie without all the "extra" stuff which is usually used (elaborate plot, music to emphasise, classical movie split). And ironically it's because this movie is *just* a movie without all the things we're so accustomed to that it's difficult for many people to enjoy. It doesn't meet what people except of movies, but if you let go of your expectations of what a movie is or how it should be and just watch it for what it is, it's a very beautiful movie.

Typical Oscar nominee...in that the art form is everything and entertaining the viewer is forgotten . films are meant to be entertaining and that is 2 hours of my life I won't get back.Lots of long shots about nothing....just a lingering shot in which maybe a plane will fly over. Sadly nothing to hold your interest as no discernible story lines to latch onto or characters to feel something for. The film ended and I don't even realise which I guess sums it up. Think the fast forward button is the best accompaniment to this picture.If you suffer from insomnia then maybe one for you....

Review title: Looks good, but a boring film
Review_body: I get that this movie looks good and is well directed, actors give a good performance and all that but it's a boring movie overall. You wait for something to happen but nothing that interesting actually does. If you're looking for an Arthouse type flick then maybe you'll enjoy it. Not for me. Don't believe the hype.

Review title: I just didn't know what to make of it..
Review_body: I just saw ROMA at the Orpheum. I'm not too sure what to make of it just yet. I either need more time to realise more or I will stay with my initial gut feel about this film's meticulous production design and editing with extraordinarily real character portrayal.Whether I invested in those portrayals I can't yet tell you. It was like a fastidiously well edited home movie. Immersive and real but at the same time, a very narrow narrative and story.It truly does makes you feel you are living in the grit of metropolitan Mexico in 1971. The attention to detail, the background action and characters, the extreme realism transports you to another time. You can smell the smoke, dust; even the detergent that cleans the pots and dishes.If you read the crits on this film you may read that some believe this to be one the best films of the decade or some such, but the reality for me was that ROMA was more of a tea ceremony. Slow, observation and a mindful diversion. Not a narrative that I bought and that affected me.ROMA is however incredibly well made and purposeful. Though I do wonder why it was released in washed out monochrome. Like I said, I just don't know what to make of it.

I just saw ROMA. I'm not too sure what to make of it just yet. I either need more time or I will stay with my initial gut feel about this film's meticulous production design and editing - with extraordinarily realistic character portrayal.Whether I invested in those portrayals I can't yet tell you. It was like a fastidiously well edited home movie. Immersive and real but at the same time, a very narrow narrative and story.It truly does makes you feel you are living in the grit of metropolitan Mexico in 1971. The attention to detail, the background action and characters, the extreme realism transports you to another time. You can smell the smoke, dust; even the detergent that cleans the pots and dishes.The performances amongst the chaos of the house and town were masterfully elicited.Some believe this to be one the best films of the decade or some such, but the reality for me was that ROMA was more of a tea ceremony. Slow, observational and a mindful diversion; and sadly not a narrative arc that I bought and that affected me.As this is a heartfelt tribute to retell the days of director, Alfonso Charon's childhood in Mexico. The length of the memory strings that pull his heart are longer for him than they are for the viewer.The languid pace of the film though conjured up two stories I love: those of novelist John Irving in his contemplative and swirling stories of family and consequence (GARP, THE CIDER HOUSE RULES); and Coppola's ode to Tokyo, LOST IN TRANSLATION. The latter was spruiked by a timeless soundtrack which helped me absorb and appreciate the characters so much. While Cuaron uses some excellent in scene, prac. musical bites (eg YELLOW RIVER and 1970's overplayed MAMY BLUES), the lack of soundtrack extinguished the sense of unity and aural theme (save the concophounous background splatter).ROMA is however incredibly well made and purposeful. The realism is a spectacle. Though I do wonder why it was released in washed out monochrome. My daughter once asked me "Dad, when you were a kid, could you see in colour too?" Yep we all sure did and we also shot in colour didn't we.Like I said, I just don't quite know what to make of ROMA.

Sometimes we forget that not only action and violence make good movies. It's a beautiful and a good story, not quite a good script, but you need to connect to the characters so you can feel what they're going through and if not, you miss the whole point of this story and you're only gonna see the perfect esthetic and photography.

Roma is a nostalgic film that takes us to a time where architecture and science was the future. Written, directed, (Co)produced, edited, and shot by Alfonso Cuaron in the beautiful Mexico City. Described as a semi autobiographical project, Cuaron handles this project with experimental finesse that reminded me of Kubrick's opening shot of the Shining. The settings quietly tell a story as clear as the dialogue between the characters. Shot in black in white and running just a little bit over two hours, Roma captivates the audience with his usage of space and depth.The opening shot is that of a closeup of the driveway, then there's a slow constant rush of water. The location is still not fully disclosed to the viewer, all you can see is a reflection of the open sky. The shot gave me the feeling of being at the bottom of a well, trapped. Then a plane soars across the sky followed by more and more suds of soap. A beautiful shot of space and reflection. It is also at this time we are introduced to the main character Cleo (Yalitza Aparicio) and the family dog Borras.Cleo and Adela (Nancy Garcia) both live in maids who work for the family. Throughout the film there will be more and more social identifiers that show a separation from the family. I get the feeling there is a Jim Crow type of law in place or maybe a caste system. The family they work for aren't the only family who have live in maids. Cuaron does a beautiful and subtle way of depicting it's normality. After Paco (Carlos Peralta) leaves Pepe (Marco Graf) on the rooftop and Paco and Cleo are staring off into space. The viewer is staring off into the distance of other rooftops of other families who live just as they do.For some reason I find a strong sense of New York City and Tokyo when I look at little details. Sure every city has an alleyway but not every city is known for their rooftops. The art deco structures and designs seen in the movie are beautifully infused with rich Mexican history.The Family, is made up of the mother Sofia (Marina de Tavrina), Dr. Antonio (Fernando Grediaga), Sofia's mother Teresa (Veronica Garcia), the eldest son Tono (Diego Autrey), their middle son Paco, Sofi (Daniela Demesa), and of course little Pepe. Sofia and Dr. Antonio work, however what seems to be a constant strain, and lie, in their relationship is that Antonio has pending business in Quebec.Sofia is a chemist and she grew on me. Her hard exterior is due to her husband's absence and infidelites. There's one scene when Sofia comes downstairs and speaks with Cleo and Pepe before Antonio comes down. She mentions to Cleo he can be late, which I believed referred more to Dr. Antonio than Pepe. He comes down and says one word to Cleo and Sofia gives him the quickest and most disgusted look. It's subtle and fast, because Sofia is clearly not the person to overshare her personal strife with the help. However, by the end of the movie you realize she is a woman of great dignity and value. By leaving a situation she plays a sign of strength to Cleo.When Cleo tells Sofia of her pregnancy with Fermin's (Jorge Guerro) baby, there is a moment I with Cleo feared she would be thrown out. Sofia instead embraces her and even takes her to her doctor appointments. On the way to an appointment Sofia purposefully squeezes Dr. Antonio's car between two vehicles on the road. She waves it off as an honest mistake to the drivers whose cars have been hit, but how else would she get away with it. This car is also a vehicle in the sense as it's something important to Dr. Antonio.Dr. Antonio and his prized car are first introduced in what could be described as a music video from the audience's perspective, but as a wrestler's entrance to the character's in the story. He slowly drives in with his cigarette and oversized luxury car. At one point he stops and adjusts the car and continues down the now narrower alley. Once he parks he exits from the passengers side, an inconvenience that would annoy any person. Once again Cuaron has us examine the smoking doctor. He's clearly going through the stereotypical depictions of a midlife crisis.It is later revealed that along with the shiny new car, Dr. Antonio has a new girlfriend in the city. He is spotted by Tono and Cleo who keep the incident a secret. Dr. Antonio is seen briefly again at the end and when Sofia tells the children she's leaving him, I don't feel bad.The scene where Sofia tells the children she's divorcing Dr. Antonio is an amazing blend of emotion. The kids are sitting around eating ice cream and Sofia breaks the news. Paco takes it the hardest crying, but the rest of the kids take it well. Paco was the middle child until Pepe came around, but he is now the middle male child. It's a coming of age moment for one child and a new bedroom to the other.Though she is not a part of the family Cleo is there to witness it all; from their morning breakfast to Sofia destroying the car after a night of drinking.Cleo and Adela do have personal lives and some freedoms. They are allowed to visit to go to the theater, which is beautifully built and designed. In this era Cuaron also highlights that going to the movies was an experience just as grand as going to a play. Once inside the theater extravagant architecture is shown in the distance and a wide screen. This could possibly be another reason why this film is in black and white, using new forms of depth and space played in the background, movies today are oversaturated and gaudy displays. But we still like it.One person who is constantly present is Teresa, another great player in this ensemble cast. During her trip with Cleo and the driver Ignacio (Andy Cortes), they are beautifully overlayed by soldiers gearing up to take on protesters. Now Cuaron does not really use a digital overlay, as it's not what he wanted to clearly avoid in this project. He simply has the soldiers trucks and equipment shot upstage as the group walks downstage behind them. It's clear that the troops have no quarrel with the middle class, they're focus is on the students. Once inside the crib store it appears the sound of chaos outside is non-diegetic as everyone continues to shop. Suddenly a group burst in and shoot a man in front of the shoppers. The camera pans and we see Fermin pointing a gun at terrified Teresa and Cleo. Fermin and Cleo are frozen in this chaos as he is faced with a decision. Fortunately he decides to take flight and is off to live a dangerous life of violence. Once Fermin flees, Cleo's water breaks.For some strange reason the color of what is supposed to be the amniotic fluids reminded me of B Horror movie blood in black and white setting. I haven researched amniotic fluids but I thought they were clear and it looked like it might've been a pepto bismol pink or orange. Who cares it's in black and white? It's just something that stood out to me amongst my heartbreaking for Cleo. Fermin had already shown signs of possible domestic abuse and psycho-fanaticism.Cleo and the group now must dodge madness and get her to the hospital. A sad moment for Cleo that leaves us hopeful for her. Once at the hospital Cleo is taken to a room as Teresa assists the nurse with what little personal information she knows about her. Once in the examination room, Cleo is transferred to an emergency surgery room. The doctors begin performing surgery and they remove a quiet baby. It is later revealed that the baby is stillborn. Cuaron once again finds beauty in the madness as there is a shot of Cleo's sweating face and it appears the focus is on her breast and then in the distance we see her baby. Who would she be a mother to? Who would she nurse?This is later revealed when Cleo travels with the family in the final family ride in Dr. Antonio's abused prized possession. When Cleo turns her back to take care of one of the other children Paco and Sofi swim and get pulled out by a strong current. Cleo rushes back and reaches and grabs both of the children out of the waves. Once on dry land Sofia returns and Cleo confesses that didn't want the baby to be born. She begin crying and Sofia tells her they lover her, everyone joins in. They all cry together. Once we return the family and Cleo go back to their routines and we are left with almost a reversal of shots showing us that it is time for the viewer to leave. A feeling reminiscent of when Mr. Rogers Neighborhood is about to end. We are then left with the view of the exterior. I'm not sure if it's to allude to passing to another side but the ending is overtly positive. Everyone is ready for a new beginning.This is an excellent film and has elements that different crowds can identify with inside of the film and outside. At times it also feels the fourth wall is blurred and then just like Cleo we are pushed out of the fantasy and into another dream-like sequence, a very controlled dream. For example Professor Zovek plays someone with a cult like following. Perfect role for professional wrestler (Latin Lover) to play. Sofia and Cleo are both strong women who will persevere despite their situations. Finally there's Pepe, the dreamer in all of us and possibly Cuaron. With all the stories he tells, you hope he becomes a great storyteller.

My family is from Mexico D.F. and from a middle class environment and many of my friends! They have lived in Mexico since the late 30's up to now and never have I witnessed that they care for a pregnant indigenous servant!!! On the contrary, the minute they discover they are pregnant, they are dismissed! I would enquire why and my answer was that Mexico had good Social Security hospitals and that the families couldn't put up with hiring these people with all the children they'd keep on having!!!

I understand why this movie is a work of art. I just don't know why it is a work of cinematic art. We are watching cinema, not video art.Underlying cinema is a story. The story has characters, that represent the complexity of the human condition - they have hopes, disappointments, successes and failures. They have different traits.Roma is a work of visual art. It has no story that captivates you. It has no characters that have any real sense of depth or complexity. If it's leading actress wins the Oscar it will be a shame. She was just a doll in Cuarón's autobiography.In a nutshell - it is boring.The leading movie critic in israel called it one of the most important movies of the century.I think the "king has no clothes".

Simplicity is Art SublimeWhat comes across as striking about this movie is its unparalleled cinematography as well as direction. The real worth of art can probably be realized when it is stripped of its frills and façade. Roma is simplicity personified but that does not stop it from being profound and sophisticated. In a nutshell, Roma is a story of a house help who works for a middle class family with four kids Paco, Toño, Sofi and Pepe,their mother Sofia and father,Antonio,a doctor who falsely claims to go to Quebec for research,leaving behind his family in lurch. The family is at the verge of falling apart albeit Cleo and Sofia are able to eke out a life of their own.One would perhaps attempt to find traces of kitchen-sink realism in this masterpiece but that seems limited only to the trope.Devil is in the detailThe wispy trance-like state that clouds the commonplace for that matter even burnt and broken things is ethereal. For instance, the manner in which the broken jar that was raised as a toast to the new year and Cleo's baby or the man who sings against the backdrop of fire somehow symbolize peace, hope and aplomb even in the eye of storm. Who would have paid attention to minute details like cleaning up dog ordure or the rubbing and scrubbing of floor reinstituting the dignity of menial labour or even exalting it,painstakingly crafted, emanating a sublime aura. It revives many images from the past such as the scene outside the movie palace with balloon sellers crying their wares and the puppeteer's words "no strings, no tricks" quite poignant at this juncture as Cleo who has been forsaken by her lover almost resembling the puppet bone man.Reminiscing the turmoil ridden periodSet in 1970s Mexico city, the movie provides oblique glimpses into the period of civil strife and dirty war in the state which resonates at the domestic front too with the severing of relations between the husband and wife, also Cleo and Fermin who professes relentless loyalty towards martial arts but chooses to abandon her the moment he hears about her pregnancy. When all the male figures have fled, one witnesses the germ of new bond which momentarily transgresses the master servant relationship.Critics aver that Cleo hasn't been given much agency,perhaps, Alfonso Cuarón tried keeping Cleo's character closer to the reality,a persona who is gritty yet chooses to not to express much in front of her superiors adhering the norms. Nevertheless, her interactions with the younger lot is unrestrained,especially her tête-á-tête with Pepe.One of the remarkable scenes in the movie is when Cleo is doing laundry and Pepe and Toño are playing a make belief game. Pepe having been shot by his brother refuses to speak as he is dead figuratively.Cleo too becomes a part of this mystic make-belief and says that she likes lying like that possibly letting her inner feelings flow thereby acknowledging that she too likes taking a break. Superficially, it seems to be Cleo's portrait which it indubitably is,herein lies the craft of the maker Alfonso Cuarón whose portrayal of the character is completely contextualized that the line between the character and the context or the content and the form is obfuscated.Alfonso Cuarón's magnum opus is a cinematic legacy for posterity just like Ingmar Bergman's and Satyajit Ray's works, timeless and universal in appeal.

Review title: I didn't know what to think
Review_body: I'm going to be honest and say I wasn't expecting a good movie. Yes the beginning is slow, but you start to get engaged and start enjoying what's happening, I'm from Mexico so it was like traveling in time to when those things used to happen. It's very good if you pay attention and stop thinking about how boring/slow the movie is. The emotion is there, the feelings of a mother losing a child she was scared to have, the acceptance, the grief. I would've liked another ending though. It was very good overall.
I want everyone to know that this movie is overrated

I really tried to get into this movie, especially given all of the awards and accolades. But this film is too slow, the storyline is pretty dull, and I'm not a fan of black and white for no reason. I guess the cinematography is beautiful but that's not really why I watch a film. I'm afraid this is another example of Hollywood or movie makers being in love with themselves and their own work. This will probably win lots of Oscars and it will be another one of those movies where I don't understand why it wins. It reminds me of Moonlight which was a decent film but not worthy of Best Picture.

I kindly recommend this to anyone who loves staring at nothing, through a still camera, for at least half of this film. Mister Alfonso Cuarón, the director, shows as things and people doing ordinary things without or with minimum dialog that will put you very fast to sleep. So, if you have trouble sleeping I also recommend this movie, is very efficient with no side effects.

Review title: A highly recommended film for all cinema lovers.
Review_body: This film which won the Best Direction and Best Foreign Language film at Oscar was really good enough to win Best Picture. Probably being a Netflix film rather than a theatrical release, the Academy was somewhat bound to be biased against it.The director is in complete command of his cinematography, camera movements and frames. The movie achieves a perfect balance of realism and grandness. The story of women and families which they hold together in 1970s mexico is shown in a moving and hard hitting manner. The third act which begins with the 1971 student protests in Mexico and the massacre that ensued leads to an enthralling climax.A highly recommended film for all cinema lovers.My rating: 9/10

Review title: Roma can leave a long lasting impression
Review_body: Roma can leave a long lasting impressionSet in the time of 1970-71 in Mexico, the movie has successfully portrayed a realistic picture of that era. Its a wonderful experience to watch this movie in black and white with the stunning cinematography. Although, there were hardly any turn or twist in the film, its realistic and linear storyline can leave a long lasting impression to the viewers . The movie is a semi-autobiographical take on the director Alfonso Cuaron's upbringing in Mexico City and he has successfully revived the details of the lifestyle of that time in the movie. Yalitza Aparicio, who played the role of an innocent maid 'Cleo' and Marina de Tavira, who played the role of the wife of a doctor were the main characters of the film and they successfully portrayed their characters. Last but not the least, the cinematographer cum director Alfonso Cuarón did a spectacular job with the long panning shots which were worth watching. Overall, you should watch the movie if you are a cinephile.

I kept waiting for something...anything to happen. But it never did. My mundane life is 10 times more interesting then the most exciting parts of this movie. Just last Sunday a plane missed crashing into my house by about 300 yards. The destruction I saw was far more dramatic then this bore of a movie. Dont waste the 2 hours this movie wants to steal from you!!!

Clearly the viewer is overawed by the monochromatic, broad sweeping and idyllic cinematography of this vastly overrated film. However, beyond that, the viewer is presented with a cookie cutter story of an upper middle class 60's era Mexican family complete with servants from a rural Mayan, Zapoteca or Nahuatl village. The middle class children bond with the servants, the mom alternates love and kindness with anger and condescension while the father carries on affair with a mistress. Small plot developments barely warrant attention such as the ubiquitous , the stereotypical boyfriend of the main servant who stupidly bores us with a martial arts stick moves while naked and exposing us to his grotesque junk, but abandons her once pregnant. The devout Catholic grandma who tries to help but prays a lot. Nothing is really resolved in the movie other than to present this horribly predictable story that closes with a group hug! The martial arts scenes are a colossal waste of cinematic effort, while the supposedly dramatic swimming in the Gulf of Mexico at Vera Cruz is hyped up solely by the sound editor blasting the volume from very rough seas yet visually presenting - what? 3 foot waves! About the only amusing part is when the family picnics with an American family that likes to shoot guns but only drink cocktails when a forest fire starts. That was funny!Is this movie Oscar material? Absolutely not! Definitely not even really Worth watching the whole movie. Protesters shooting up with other people? Uhhh....run of what mill 3rd world everyday stuff. The title? Roma? What's the point of that? It's the euphemism for Gypsies. How is that even remotely relevant to this cookie cutter story of self-inflicted injustice in a 3rd world country?
Summary: Overrated! Nothing New or Revelatory!

Anyone that thinks this is a great film is welcome to watch my Bar Mitzvah movies. I spent 2 hours watching this waiting for something to happen. It's now 2 or 3 hours later and I've completely forgotten all about it.

3 Óscars... Really?
This is one of the worst movies I have seen..
I waited for something major to happen and it didn't. The movie is the definition of scam,all that hype for nothing.
I know that Mexico submitted ROMA for the best foreign language film at this year's Oscars, but it deserves a best picture nomination. This film is nothing less than breathtaking and captivating

One off for the perfect arty shots that may appeal to mostly art house movie goers. The two main men are in positions of power but weak in character and the two main woman are in weak positions and after chaos find strength and power. Every aspct of the film works together creating a unified whole.

As a Mexican-American, I am always happy to see other Latinos succeeding--but we can do better than this. This film is about the life of women in the 70's in semi-rural mexico--hard, little options, often dictated by the whims of men. And, nothing much else. I suppose that for those that have little knowledge of challenges women would face in Mexico at that time, it may be groundbreaking. In fact, that's the only way I could make sense of this winning so many awards. But as I found nothing shocking, it was a waste of time to watch. Boring, such basic character development, and only paints the women as victims with some slight autonomy at some points. Skip it.

Please bear in mind that this film is in black and white , is subtitled , nothing much happens and is very long . If you're not put off by any of that you may well love it but the majority of "everyday " people will be bored witless

Many of us find this film boring and it's really not for everyone as very little happens . You have to wonder why it scores so highly at 7.8 . Are the low scores being ignored . I understand that many love it but surely the scoring should be fairer

I just don't get why this movie is hailed as such a great film. Technically yes, but it comes off as an art house film with hidden meanings. There really was no connection to the characters. What is the re-watch factor for this film as the true great ones? Zero for me. Very disappointed.

Quiet in its tone and subdued in its essence, Roma slowly creeps into the audience's consciousness and tells us a story of human fortitude that has not been exaggerated for cinematic flair. Roma is a deeply personal movie. The story being too familiar, nothing in the movie surprises you. But with an elaborate cinematography and slow camera movements, the movie is able to shine the light on moments that we would not have otherwise paused to reflect on. In its idleness, the movie reveals the complexities of human character and and its ability to rally against unforeseen circumstances. It is a story of hope and courage.
The movie is filled with metaphors. There are so many scenes that deserve an essay of their own. However, I feel its best if I were not to betray these details, before you could watch and form your own reflections. A lot of the movie feels more like a poetry. The black and white theme certainly helps build that feeling.
Everything about the movie feels beautiful and familiar and that, in my opinion, is the triumph of Roma.

Review title: Beautiful nihilism. I thought it was impossible, but Roma proved me wrong.
Review_body:
The cinematography and directing, I don't even have to address it. It's flawless.
The story, which many complain about, is not direct and it's for a damn good reason. We watch these movies nowadays and we expect a fairytale ending in everything. Well here's what Roma tells all of us, especially us middle class and upper class: if you wanted a fairy tale ending, you're on the wrong fkin planet.
A wasteland of a movie. Truly awful. Slightly interesting cinematography cannot rescue this briefest.
Totally Boring. A Narrative Failure. Excellent photography and ambient but a huge failure regarding story tellingMade to appear to be good but really bad
It is just an OK movie, certainly does not deserve to be rated >8/10. If I knew what it was, I wouldn't have wasted my time on this movie.

Near perfection. Reels you in effortlessly. It's been a long time since I've seen something this understated feel so moving and impactful. I was definitely reminded of Fellini at times. Rooting for this as an awards contender for Best Film, Best Director, and Best Cinematography. The acting was on point too. So many layers that it will keep me thinking about it for days.
It's a tossup-Roma or A Ghost Story (Casey Affleck) deserve the award for the dullest movie of the year.

Review title: Worth all the Oscar nominations, even more
Review_body: Absolutely stunning. Makes me very happy that there are people, actors, camera, director, you name it, who make such art.

Film engaged me from the very beginning, i thought i couldn't pull it through because language is a barrier but when you see a art it reflect the real emotions, for understanding art like this you have to understand the emotions.
Very simple story if there is any. Unnecessarily long and boring. Shallow characters, no in-depth analysis. Slow tempo and black&white?

Just a few moments in this film and one can guess it's caliber. some of the scenes are so well put-together that they take you into them like the entry of sofia's husband, the wildfire, children drowning. and with the awesome use of camera panning and effects it just enhances it's beauty. The depiction of class heiraachy is with so much accuracy and actors play it so well.
Yes, the filming itself was artistic and wonderful... But getting through this movie was a chore. I love a good story, but in Roma I was left deeply unsatisfied.

Every single frame of this film is brilliant. It's not just his use of long takes -- it's HOW he uses long takes. It's not just his inclusion of non-actors -- it's the dignity with which they move on screen. 10/10.
What a great film. From story telling, to cinematography, everything's perfect.

Review title: HORRIBLE! There are less painful ways to waist 2+ hours
Review_body: POS. One of the worst films ever. Super-simple cinematography; just tripod mounted shots. There are less painful ways to waist 2+ hours.

Review title: For those that say that don't make 'um like that anymore, they do
Review_body: Just a bit slow to start and parts remain unclear to me (the various marches in the street - why did no one play with the dogs?). Don't stop watching - movie is visual treat of a production. Every angle and frame was a story in itself. The black & white works, works well - yet Mexico is such a lovely country, was some of that lost with the B&W? The parallels in situation between the staff and family is not lost, both have needs, both have dog crap all over their lives.

Review title: Powerful yet understated and intentionally so
Review_body: The story being told is sublime and raw. A film so captivating in a world full of big budget action and overly celebratised films. Truly special.

I want to start my review by saying that I am Mexican. I find incredible, how Alconfo Cuarón took disconnected events happening within a family and sew together its parts to create this majestic piece of art.Many non-mexicans won't understand some of the background symbolisms, like the very known sounds of the vendors in the streets, or the interactions between such a common "family" (for many of us).My family, for many years, was very similar to the one portrayed in the story. My mom had to find help, when she and my father divorced, so our Cleo came into our lives. I was 5 and my sister 4, and our grandma was also around to help. The bond of our family was so strong that when we had to move to a completely different state, our Cleo came with us. And such as in the movie, my sister was once drawning in the sea and she was the first to realise and went to help, regardless of her not knowing how to swim.All these resemblances to my life, made this movie extremely special for me. But that is not what makes it so special. For me the magic takes place when Cuarón shows you his life (and that of many of us) by allowong the viewers to (kind of) peek through the windows of the family and makes the ordinary become extraordinary.As mentioned before, his delicate attention to details makes you realise that there is nothing left to chance in this movie. Everything is played just as in his mind, following the script of life.The acting of both leading ladies is also worth noticing, is obvious that even the casting had to be perfect and I believe it was. They conveyed the huge array of emotions of everyday life. Heartbreak, love, distrust, sadness, deep melancholy, you name it. Without these two women, the movie wouldn't be complete.The settings, backgrounds and even what I've heard as "the unnecessary long boring intro" blend perfectly good. The camerawork is incredible. The fact that is filmed in black and white had concerned me before starting the movie, but once watching, the black and white made it feel like is one of those flashbacks in the middle of a movie/TV show (I wonder if that is what Cuarón wanted us to feel).I loved to see the beaches of my beloved Tabasco in the movie, so sad they said they were going to Veracruz instead. I was wondering for some time why the scene of the sea looked so familiar, until I saw the blue crab and understood it was right there were my Cleo saved my sister's life.Please watch it with an open mind (especially to the Mexicans out there saying it is so boring or that they can't relate). We can all relate, it is the essence of life itself, human interaction, AMOR.

Every now and then a movie comes along that reviewers who want to appear sophisticated and "in the know" feel compelled to heap all kinds of praise upon. This is one of those movies. Boring, slow, tedious, and lame don't begin to describe it. Hate is a strong word, but it is the only appropriate one to describe my feeling towards this waste of film. I honestly don't see how any real human being could like or enjoy this movie, and I suspect that very few actually did, despite their phony reviews.

Review title: A breathtaking cinematic masterpiece. Alfonso Cuarón has done it again.
Review_body: Alfonso Cuarón packs his unique style into arguably one of the decades most beautiful films. His signature long shots are absolutely stunning, and if you've seen any of his other films (Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Gravity, Y Tu Mamá También) you'll notice that he adds every bit of his style Cuarón from visual symbolism and imagery, to complex takes.There is so much in this movie to unpack, like the rich history of Mexico and it's politics during Echeverría's presidency, to a very common household and the relationship between employee and employer. The film talks through it's imagery, containing themes of family, love, abandonment and so much more.I don't want to say any spoilers, but the scene in the beach near the end of the movie is one of the most beautiful and complex takes I have ever seen in any movie. Hats off to Cuarón for making such an incredible piece of art, and hopefully it gets the recognition and praise it deserves.

Most of the reviews on here say that this film is all style and no substance, but i wholeheartedly disagree. The story isn't a grandiose adventure, but there's so much going on under the surface. You become attached to Cleo until everything she goes through becomes your own emotional burden. The story is slow paced, but very interesting the more you pay attention.I think this is a great film with beautiful cinematography and an emotional story, it definitely deserved all the awards it won.

Now I'll be honest. If you read about this film being the best ever like I did you'll most likely be somewhat confused and dissapointed.
If you take into account the film and video performance then you'll be more understanding.
Film making connoisseurs would love the art of this film where the wannabe connoisseurs would attack you for your 'low star' review.
I watched this movie for the share value of the storyline and not the camera work. I would have been more gracious had this been advertised better by professional critics.
I'm writing this on how I felt after watching the movie rather than after reading more about this after watching
If anyone else had made this movie it would have gone nowhere. Boring. I attempted it twice after reading great reviews but gave up.
This is how i was after watching this, i don't know it feels so personal, intimate. I was feeling like i was in someone else privice, kinda this.
Simply, the film worth watching! Thanks for Alfonso Cuarón for this incredible masterpiece!

Review title: What the buzz is all about??!!
Review_body: No story, no plot, no twist it was so boring I had to fast forward some parts to get to some exciting parts but there was none of that. My 4 stars is for the cinematography and the last half hour of the film.

BORING! It was all I could do not to turn it off. As someone else said, it's like watching paint dry. A movie should grab you in the first 10 minutes, we'll this one won't. He spent almost a minute on a scene with birds in a cage.

Review title: Roma: The Precise Film Making of Alfonso Cuaron
Review_body: This film is one of the most beautiful pieces of film that I have ever seen. Cuaron's directing is so precise and the camera work is impressive beyond belief. There were multiple scenes where I asked, "How was this even made?" or scenes where I watched in awe. The narrative was also super engaging and brought up some many complex, emotional themes. It had me in tears at multiple points of the film. The tone and pacing of the film was a high point as well. The constant tone shifts resembled a sense of reality as did the struggles. The complex political themes were subtle enough to not get in the way, but poignant enough to stick with me way after watching the film. The audio design was also incredible, and I recommend watching this with the best sound possible. Overall, I expected great film making more than a compelling narrative, but I got easily received both. Cuaron's style is a personal favorite of mine, and his interesting and fresh style of film making is present in this film as well.

Review title: An explanation as to why critiques may like this film
Review_body: This was a very atmospheric experience with undoubtedly skilled cinematography. In particular, it was clear that the camera took advantage of the spacious scenery. The panning technique was used effectively with wider shots and the length of most shots fitted the tone overall. The acting was REALLY well done, even the child actors did not disappoint. The use of the black and white filter automatically made the whole experience even more depressing than it should be, which is actually what I believe the film aimed to do. The good thing tha came out from this choice of filter is the fact that it didn't take away from the beauty of the film. There were still amazing still frame shots and scenery, proving that colour is not at all necessary for a good cinematographic experience, with every detail still clear and concise and the different shades still accounting for the different colours. It is clear that Cuaron took a massive amount of time and effort even in the filter, making sure the details in the film are still seen without a problem. You could only imagine how much effort went into this piece. The first half of the movie took me a while to get into (not sure whether or not it's because I was not in the right mindset for this type of film). I usually prefer movies that are a bit more fast paced than this, so I would prefer if the first half was a little shorter, but I understand the artistic choice of going at the pace this movie is set as characters had to be developed to establish a connection between them and the viewer for later, more emotional scenes. The second half however, took me by surprise. I felt like I was embraced by the movie, standing alongside with other characters during the scene where they shopped for a crib. The fact that such an innocent and pure activity could turn into a mass attack really shocked me. I don't usually get too emotional out of shock to the point of tears, but something about the birth scene got to me. Maybe it's something about having a side view of the baby literally dying in front of it's mother while being blurred in the background. Safe to say, second part of the movie was much much better, with the plot resolving and themes coming together. The end scene at the beach was very powerful too, and it's even more impressive knowing that it was shot in one take. I'm new to analysing movies, so maybe I did not see the point in some scenes that I found out flat out boring and unnecessary, but I could say with confidence that this movie deserved to win best cinematography as it used simple techniques (which fit very well with the setting) to explore and be creative with the space given.I would watch this again and maybe I will understand more of it and give it at least 9 stars. But that's what I look for in a movie, to make me think and raise questions after watching.

Review title: 2 hour long walking and talking commercial
Review_body: This is by far the movie that has frustrated me the most. A movie is supposed to be digital storytelling, I repeat STORYtelling. If a movie has no plot and no direction then what is the point other than if you enjoy watching people walk around and talk senselessly for hours in black and white. Yes it's pretty and the cinematography is more than there, but that's not what you rely on to create a movie, especially when that's all that's there. Overall this is a lazy attempt at movie making that somehow surpassed the academy and has duped them into handing them awards for it. You can't film people doing pointless things for 2 straight hours, include no plot, slap a title on there, and call it a movie.
This is a movie with heart. My sense of morality grew from watching Roma and for the insemination of moral sensitivity this film deserves its awards. Sympathy to the ones who come away empty handed.

A perverse relationship of convenience
" In the same breath it's: 'We really love you, but go and wash the clothes, and bring the Twinkie wonders, and make a smoothie for me"

I don't know where to begin with this film. There is so much to observe, but I wanna start with cinematography, the panning, tracking, framework, depth of field was all taken into consideration and brought a deeper meaning to the film. It was visually stunning and I felt like I was apart of this world, a spectator simply observing, which is what you want in film, you want it to feel real. In almost every scene there is a story being told in the background and foreground. The story was told from the point of view of Cleo, one of two domestic workers helping Antonio and Sofia take care of their 4 children. Problems arises when Antonio leaves Sofia and the family and runs away with another woman. Cleo got pregnant and had miscarriage. The story brings up the whole theme of acceptance and challenges of single parenthood as we see Sofia struggle to raise the 4 children. The production was so well done and really shows you what life was like in 1970s Mexico. Overall this movie was a great watch and visually pleasing. There is a lot more to the movie than what was said in this review.

Alfonzo Cuarón delivers a meloncholy yet beautiful journey through 1970s La Roma, Mexico in this picturesque and eerily realistic story of loneliness and belonging.Yalitza Aparicio stars as Cleo, the quiet, caring house keeper for a wealthy family headed by the matriarch Sofia (Marina De Tavira). We follow the family- and Cleo- through the excitement and dangers of living in such a bustling and lively city, as well as the emotional attachments we as humans develop for one another. It questions what we conceive as 'family' and how we cope with sadness and stress.Cuarón orchestrates a huge cast of extras and breathes life into Roma, so much so you forget you are watching a film and instead get drawn into a perfect amalgamation of choreography and the documenting of a family routine.The cinematography and sound editing are breathtaking. The black and white, sweeping camera shots and central framing of scenes bring a calmness to the madness, which in turn exentuates the subtle performances of all the main cast and make you feel like you are part of this living, breathing world.Newcomer Yalitza brings her character to life with a subtlety and realism that makes you connect with her story from the word go. Whilst avoiding spoilers- her quest for love and being a part of 'something more' goes through many peaks and troughs. Characters she considered close are unable to remember her name or age and are left abondoning her during her most vulnerable moments. The performance from Yalitza (and the four child actors) take you on an emotional rollercoaster, leaving you with questions like: "can Cleo realise who her real family are?" and "who in her life genuinely cares for her?" . It's down to Cleo to find that "perfect balance" in her life that she doesn't know she is capable of possessing.The only issue for me was the pacing of the movie. In some areas the movie dragged and became a bit mundane and monotonous (I now realise that this probably symbolises the life our characters are leading- but it still felt a little too slow in areas). The phrase style over substance came to mind many times, but with the crescendo of emotional tension during the film's climax, it builds to an incredie final act that may leave you wanting more.With beautiful metaphor (a car not being the "right fit" for the garage and the frequent planes signalling a "daydream" like life that always seems too far to reach) the film tugs on the heart strings, makes you fall in love with the main characters and takes you back to a hectic childhood in Mexico that you never had. Cuarón delivers and I highly recommend you watch this film on Netflix right now!8.5/10

Review title: Fellini + Herzog + Jodorowsky + Hispanic soap-opera = Roma
Review_body:
The implication of that title may make you think Roma is one hell of a movie.
It's not.The critics had me looking forward to this movie more than any other in recent memory.
An artistic film with both both style AND substance they said. Just what I like.I was captivated by the opening sequence, the movie had my undivided attention.
I watch intently waiting to witness the magic of cinematic genius unfolding before me.
I wait and watch. Wait and watch.
An hour passes and I feel like there's something I'm failing to grasp.
Another 30 minutes pass and I really hope I haven't wasted my time.
Another 30 minutes go by and the movie is drawing to a close and I am dissapointed.
The movie ends and I feel swindled, conned, duped.
The critics have done it again!Not to compose a total hatchet job i'd like to point out that the sound design throughout was exceptional with the Dolby Atmos soundscape using directional sound to it's full potential, immersing me in the setting portrayed on screen.
I imagine the movie also did a good job of representing the era and location with authenticity.Now for the hatchet job:
I take exception to the critics assertions that every scene is beautiful because they're just not. One imdb user review even told me my Jaw would be on the floor throughout.
Truth is, most scenes are just functional, framed just as they should be with the choice to present the movie in B&W imbueing the scenes with a gravitas that wouldn't be present if it was in full colour.There are 3 or 4 scenes throughout the entire movie that stood out as being visually unique in their beauty and 2 or 3 others that fell too far into pretentiousness to fully appreciate their artistic merit.The themes of life, death, family and the human condition are always good fodder for a thoughtful drama but when the characters are lacking personality, the script is sparse and the story is threadbare it is very difficult for the viewer to care.
Even the intended climatic scenes are anti-climatic and fall flat.Personally, I found this movie lacking in both style and substance.But what about the symbolism and hidden
meanings you say? In this case, convenient devices to to make a dull movie appear deeper than it is.
I'm sure it's all very personal and meaningful for Cuaron but then he has tangible experiences to flesh out the bones of this story.Ultimately, I feel this was an exercise in mundane authenticity punctuated by just enough plot to keep the viewer interested in the hope that it gets better.
It doesn't.

Review title: a masterpiece for the ones that enjoy stories.
Review_body: This is a movie i would describe with any words other than "a movie". It is a visual novel. A photograph that tells a thousand stories. It is not only perfect, but in black and white, and is my favorite movie to date.

Everone else has written about the great camerawork but how boring the movie was, so I won't add anything else.
To me it was an odd love story. The love an employer has for an employee who becomes almost a part of the family.
Read Roma backwards and you get Amor. Need I say more?
At first i really got bored but the last 30 minutes saved the whole movie, it has nice cinematography and camera work is awesome, other things were pretty mediocre.

Review title: What it when you are in good mood and have enogh time to absorb
Review_body: This movie put you right inside Mexico City in 1970s. The actings are beyond real and the main actress deserves at least Oscar nomination. The shots usually lasts longer than you expect but it is still interesting because of beautiful shades of grey in amazing black and white scenes. However, the story is so thin that prevents Roma from being a perfect movie.Watch it only when you are in good mood and you have three hours to watch and absorb a movie that someone may found boring!

I've rated over 400 films and never felt the need to write a review until now. I'm getting so sick of movies about absolutely nothing receiving such high ratings. Boyhood. Ladybird. Moonlight and now Roma. Since when did movies about mundane people living their ordinary lives become masterpieces in cinema?

Firstly the photography is beautiful, love the locations, the textures and the feeling behind them. The sound is magical too, beeping horns, birds, dogs barking, it felt like I lived there for a little while.However the story was slow, it had its moments of drama interspersed with long long scenes. The ending felt quite rushed compared to the first parts and I was a little confused about Cleo's status in the family, sometimes belittled sometimes treated like a family member - maybe that's how maids are treated?It's different, it's enjoyable, it's not the worst 'critically acclaimed' movie but if you enjoy action, pace, romance and mainstream movies this probably isn't for you :)

This film is beautifully shot. The acting is excellent. The plot? Just goes nowhere. I so wanted to like or love this movie, but the story line just meanders somewhat aimlessly on a road to nowhere. If I might summarize: it's a story about a domestic (maid / housekeeper) in a middle class household in Mexico City in 1970. That's it. There was no real beginning or end; it was a chapter or 2 or 3 pulled from a diary of someone leading an ordinary life.
Hate Black and white films .that make you snore.Cinematography does not make a great movie

Review title: Slow, shots linger in way too long
Review_body: I am baffled by the outpouring of love for this film. I found it so incredibly slow and boring (so pretty much par for the course for a Best Pic nominee). Shots linger on way too long, and there's useless extra shots that serve no purpose. The movie doesn't seem to have any point to it whatsover. And add to that the needless use of black and white-we have the technology to film in color, there is no excuse not to do so! Overrated artsy garbage.

This movie is not for the impatient or the unfocused. If you are in one of those categories, don't even bother. Not all movies are supposed to be easily digestible.I've never watched a movie that felt so real and it's a long time since I've been glued to the screen like this one, not out of suspense, but out of identification and synchronicity.Others have described the stunning cinematography; it is not only beautiful, it tells half the story as well and gives presence. The synthesis of all elements in this movie came together so seamless, there was nothing to do but to give myself away completely for the duration.

Cinema is not painting gallery. Poor critics dont know this yet!!
The diff between cinema & painting gallery is screenplay. Roma completly has no screenplay and no character. Cinema is not a box that you put every subject(content) to it. You can put one or two things to it and try to zoom on those subjects. Simple & deep. Roma taste nothing. Its not about being mother, its not about killing students, its not about divorce, its not about misery, its not about district Roma, its not about oppressed women. Roma is about nothing. History of Cuaron's family maid is NOT dramatic & not important for others.
Alfonso cuaron is a smart guy who has deceived critics all over the world.

This movie is great if you like, nay, if you love camera panning. There is so much panning,
it's truly fantastic. Very artistic. 90 degrees, 180 degrees, once even 450 degrees!! Oh and tracking also. Panning and tracking, tracking and panning, panning and tracking galore. And just when you think "wow, this panning has been so great and so abundant, they can't possibly squeeze in any more!" well, right at that moment you're in for a treat. No spoilers, you will need to see for yourself what treat I mean. Oh, there's also a story in there somewhere about a middle class family in the Mexico in the 70s, marital problems and a Mixtec indigenous live-in household help. But I truly don't think any of that is really relevant to the movie, at least not as much as the panning.

Wow. Finally got round to watching Roma, and I'm highly ashamed that it's taken so long.It's a bona fide masterpiece. Sweeping and grand, yet incredibly intimate. There's a new superhero in town, her name is Cléo and her power is pure love. Yalitza Aparicio gives a performance that is probably one of the best I'll ever have the privelege to witness. No hyperbole; just flat fact. It's a knockout masterclass in naturalistic performance unmatched by any actor this year.Literally every frame of this picture is magical; like being given the chance to live inside a memory. You won't see anything else this year that's so visually ravishing, yet completely spellbinding.Deeply moving, incredibly profound and shot through with a verité that no other movie has brought to the table for a very long time, Roma might actually be a contender for film of the decade for me, and potentially this century, to date...

It's simply an ANNOYING film to watch, the sound track is there to annoy you on purpose, the lack of colors too. I won't get deep into analyzing the work but I would say that it's a failed attempt to creat something genuine

Review title: There are two kinds of movies. Roma is the epitome of the second.
Review_body: Both types are perfectly legitimate and I love both.First: movies as entertainment. A place to lose oneself. I just saw all three of the Lord of the Rings movies here in a theater in Minneapolis over New Year's Eve weekend, 2018. Back to back. To see them again on a big screen was wonderful and I appreciated, all over again, how Peter Jackson (the director), combined so many elements (story adaptation, casting, acting, visuals, special effects) to create a world I was happy to lose myself in, for hours. (Trust me it was hours.) When they're good we all love movies like this. I know I do.Second: movies as an experience or lesson. A place to find oneself. Most of David Lynch's films fall here. A fair amount of Bergman. Some Kubrick (2001 for sure; maybe Barry Lyndon). Lost in Translation. And Roma. Really any movie where the user reviews on IMDB are either 8-9-10 or 1-2-3. And the latter are filled with words like "boring" and "nothing happens."A suggestion if you're in the latter group: stop trying to figure these movies out. Stop waiting for something classically entertaining to happen. Just turn off your brain and stop thinking. Let the movie roll over you (frankly this is the only way to watch a Lynch movie that isn't "The Straight Story" or "Dune"). Be open and emphatic.When it's over you may find yourself with some subtle, emotional reaction you can't obviously describe (unlike a response to the first kind where typically we know exactly what we liked and didn't like). But you feel moved in someway: sad, filled with joy, terrified. These movies can expose you to or remind us what it means, authentically, to be human. And that kind of movie won't leave you for a long, long time.This isn't to say that some who love the second type can't be pretentious. I roll my eyes at lots of these user reviews sometimes. Ignore them. Find your own way.Think of it this way: loving both kinds of movies just gives you more movies to see and enjoy!

I grew up in the 70's so maybe that is why this film resonates and the feel of this era is so superbly put to life on the screen.
We follow Cleo, a housekeeper in a middleclass family in Mexico. And the way this movie depicts her day to day life in the household is just so real. Each scene is like an amazing pictureframe and is shot with beautiful precision. I really feel for Cleo during her very emotional struggles in life. I found this movie beautiful and emotional. Cuarón has made a movie he can be really proud of.
